div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1904.

div.head: PROPOSED SMALL-POX HOSPITAL.
div.p: While we hope that the correspondence in our columns which has followed the recent lamentable death of a young Englishman in the Deaconesses' Hospital will be productive of some result, and that the establishment of an isolated small-pox hospital for the treatment of Europeans who may be attacked by that terrible disease is a thing of the near future, we also sincerely trust that the occasion may not be made the opportunity for an attack on the excellent institution at which the death of Yousbashi Armstrong took place. Englishmen should be thankful that such an institution as the Deaconesses' Hospital exists in Alexandria. We know of a case-a surgical ne-treated there last year with the utmost medical skill and nursing attention, both successful to a degree that would have reflected the highest credit on the best of our London | hospitals. The patient, a clerk in the office of one of our great shipping companies, came to Egypt with his wife for the benefit of a sea voyage, but was in so seriousa state on his arrival that an operation of a difficult nature had to be performed. The wife remained in the hospital with ar husband during the few weeks he staye. there, the charge for board and residence in both cases being, we believe, P.140 per day. They at least, have occasion to be thankful for the existence of the Deaconesses' Hospital and for the medical skill Drs. Morrison and Nauphal, supplemented, as it was, by the excellent nursing of the devoted women who, without monetary recompense, so carefully and cheerfully attend the sick pe lients uuder their charge. While Englishmer can receive such attention as this, it seems somewhat premature to think of establishing en English Cottage Hospital here, especially in view of the limited success that has attended the Anglo-American Hospital in Cairo, where the English-speaking residents far outuumber tholb in Alexandria and where even the influentii support the new institution has received from Lord Cromer and others has failed to bring in its trait the general support without which sucess is impossible.

div.head: THE CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: While the significance of the progressive increase of death from bovine typhus which has been noted dring the last month may be easily exaggerated, and while there is no reason to apprehānd any really heavy mortality in the future, we must warn our readers not to entertain too sa guine hopes of an early and complete disappearance of the epidemic. It is probable that univourable climatic conditions, want of sun, raid weather, etc., are to a large degree responsibl for this increase, but not a few men who are qualified to advance their opinions of the subject are inclined to consider it probal le that the cattle plague will continue with us for another two years, though the inocilation of surviving animals and other med ures taken by the Sanitary Department, coupled with the fact that a disease exhausts itself, i.e., becomes in popular parlance "worked out,” will prevent any mortality on a large scale in the future.

div.head: PHARMACY REGULATIONS. The pharmacists of Alexandria and Cairo are still in bata re the new regulations, and we understand that a certain proportion of them are clined to submit as gracefully as possible to the obnoxious second article. With referen to this article, we quite understand the feelings of the pharmacists and the publiwho prefer the proprietor of a pharmacy to be a qualified chemist, but are not they reckoning without their host in assuming that a modification of the regulations in that sense would command the unqualified assent of the Powers! If our memory does not fail us, a proposal similar to that now made by the pharmacists led to some of the last Pharmacy Regulations issued by the Government, in fact formed part of the law on the subject, but these were never applied owing to the obstructive action of certain Powers under the Capitulations:
BECK & CO'S PILSENER BEER

div.head: ATTEMPTED ISOLATION
div.p: The latest Japanese successes at Port Arthur indicate that the Japanese are endeavouring to isolate the Liao ti shan promontory. (Reuter.)
Tokio, December 26. The S.S. "Manshu Maru " left for Port Arthur with 10 foreign attachés, representatives, of the Diet, and press representatives on board.
(Reuter.

div.head:
TOKIO A MILITARY CAMP.
ENORMOUS MILITARY PREPARATIONS.
div.p: Tokio, December 26. Tokio is again a great military camp, repeating the scenes of last Spring. Thousands of recruits and reservists have assembled, and are being drilled and equipped preparatory to taking the field. The barracks are full, and soldiers are billeted throughout the city

The general military preparations are enormous. It is proposed to give Oyama, roughly speaking, half a million men, together with a heavy increase in his artillery, besides provid. ing for the defence of Formosa and the Southern Islands. The latter is in anticipation of the Baltic Fleet attempting to seize a base.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
RUSSIAN REVOLUTIONARY RIOTS.
TROOPS FIRED ON.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, December 26. During a revolutionary demonstration yesterday at Radom Poland), where mobilisation is proceeding, the demonstrators fired upon the troops. The colonel and one demonstrator were killed
(Reuter.)

div.head: FRANCE AND MOROCCO.
div.p: PARIS, December 26. The eventuality of a naval demonstration and the seizure of the Customs of Morocco has been under consideration by the Government in the event of the Sultan not giving satisfaction.
(Hanas.

div.head: NEW GREEK CABINET.
div.p: ATHENS, December 26. M. Delyannis will form the Cabinet. The Chamber of Deputies will be dissolved.
(Havas.)

div.head: PARIS RAILWAY COLLISION.
div.p: Paris, December 26. Thirteen persons were killed and 32 injured in the recent collision here.
(Reuter.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Buy Hassan is expected to arrive at Suez on the 12th prox. from Yokohama, Singapore, and Colombo. His Highness will have then completed the tour round the world which he undertook for the benefit of his health. Prince Aziz, it will be remembered, left Genoa for America on September 22, 80 will have completed his tour in 3 months.
Sir Howard Vincent, M.P., has left Grosvenor square for Paris, en route to Khartoum, and will return at the end of January.

Mrs. McCalmont and a party of friends, in. cluding Sir Maurice FitzGerald, Colonel Grierson, Mrs. Legge, Mr. Hago De Bathe and one or two others, leave England for Egypt about January 4, and expect to be a way till March. They will go as far as Khartoum.
Lord and Lady Craven are also coming to Egypt this winter, and they start very shortly. They do not return till March or April:

div.p: To-morrow (Wednesday) a concert will be given by the full Tsigane Band at Shepheard's from 9 to 11 p.m.

div.head: SHARAKI LAND.
div.p: --The final estimate of this year's sharaki land puts it at about 70,000 feddans, involving a reduction of taxation of L.E. 42,000.

div.p: -Madama Butterfly was produced at this theatre last night and met with the same snecess as on the previous production.

div.p: -M. Maspero basf I been chosen to represent the Government au I the Archaeological Congress which will be held at Athens next month.

div.head: GHEZREH PALACE.
div.p: -The first small dance at Ghezireh Palace will be held on Thursday next. These dances will take place every Thursday, during the season.

div.head: "Suez Canal.
div.p: -- On Friday 23rd inst. 11 vesseis passed through the Caual, 5 of which were British, 1 German, 1 Dutch, 1 Egyptian, 1 Austrian, 2 Turkish. The receipts for the day were frs. 234,092.71, bringing the total amount received from the Ist inst. to frs. 7,862,426.46.

div.head: H. M. TRANSPORT
div.p: "Assaye" (Capt. E. R. Dowell, R.N.R.), arrived at Port Said early yesterday morning from Bombay with 1,193 li troups of all ranks on board. The officer commanding is Lieut.-Col. D. A. McFarlane, King's Own Scottish Borderers. The "Assaye ett for Southampton at 10 a.m.

div.head: SHEIKH BARGHOUT.
div.p: -A sum of L.E. 150,000 is to be set apart in the coming year for the creation of a maritime terminus for the SuakiuAtbara railway at Sueikh Barghout. The name of the future greatest port in the Red Sea is to be changed, but what its official desigua tion is to be has not yet been decided on.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR Court.
div.p: -No official alnouncement has yet been made as to who is to be the new judge of the Supreme Consular Court Judge and Mrs. de Sausmarez letu Constantinople last week. On Friday week they held a largely-attended farewell reception at the British Hotel at Constantinople.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: -A new branch of this bank will be opened at Port Said in the beginuing of January. Mr. Fould, late manager at the agency at Medinet el-Fayoum, will take charge of the new branch. It is also intended to open other new agencies in the provinces, but the dates or places have not been finally decided on.

div.head: INSPECTIONS.
div.p: - The G.O.C. will inspect the 2nd Co. R.E. at Kasr-el-Nil, at 9 a.m. on the 5th January. The followiug are the probable |dates of the G.O.C. s, inspection of the under mentioned units in Cairo :-9th January, A.S.C., 10th January, A.0.0.; 12th January, Det., 2nd Rifle Brigade ; 16th January, R.A.; 23rd January, 2nd Royal Inniskilliug Fusiliers.

We regret that we cannot insert this, religious controversy being one of those things we make it a rule never to encourage in our columns.

div.head: The "TIMES OF Egypt.
div.p: "-Hanna Bey B&coum, the well-known official of the Ministry of Justice, whose former connection with the | Thewfikieh Company brought his name into prominence lately, has brought an action against the Editor of the defunct Times of Egypt, for having, he alleges, abused him near Pont Limoun. The case came before a petty native court in Cairo & few days ago. The further hearing of the case was postponed until next month.

div.head:
BIG ALEXANDRIA FIRE. WALKER AND MEIMARACHI'S
STORES GUTTED.
ENORMOUS DAMAGE.
div.p: At an early hour this morning, a destructive fire broke out in the very heart of Alexandria. The scene of the conflagration was the Old Exchange Buildings (Palais de l'Ancienne Bourse). The north portion of the ground floor of this block of buildings is occupied by the editorial and printing offices of the Egyptian Gazette, the large store of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Limited, is in the centre, while on the south side is the large and luxuriously appointed bar belonging to the same firm. The whole of the upper portion of the building is used as a cigarette factory, and belongs to Messrs. E. Laurens & Co., the manager of which firm is the owner of the building.

It is believed that the fire arose through the fusing of some electric wires affixed to the ceiling at the back of Messrs. Walker & Meimarachi's bar, where the grill is situated. Shortly before 2 o'clock, while the bar was still open, one of the employés saw that the ceiling in this part of the establishment was on fire. The habitués and bar tenders quickly evacuated the building, and by the time the Alexandria Fire Brigade made its appearance, the fire had gained great hold over the inflammable contents, and had spread to the bar. The flames leaped across the street, and if a strong wind had been blowing Saint Mark's Buildings would have caught fire, as well as the great pile of buildings which have been erected by Messrs. Allen and Alderson on the other side of Old Bourse-street. Fortunately the scaffolding around the latter building has recently been taken down. Otherwise it would inevitably have caught. Owing to the exertions of the Fire Brigade, under the command of Miralai Wapkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, and of the superintendent of the Fire Brigade, Sagh. Lynn, the fire was prevented from spreading across the street, but it gained complete mastery over the bar, which was absolutely gutted. The fire made its way to the cigarette manufactory on the first floor, and dense volumes of smoke came from the upper windows, while it spread with equal swiftuess to the grocery and provision stores in the centre on the ground floor. The entrances and windows of this store were broken into and the firemen poured an endless stream of water on the contents, which included a great supply of valuable 'Xmas and New Year presents. Almost all the goods were destroyed by the fire or rendered valueless by the water.

It is as yet impossible to determine the extent of the loss either in the case of the property of Messrs. Walker & Meimarachi or of Messrs. Laurens & Co. The fire was got well under control by 5 o'clock, and was successfully prevented from reaching our offices. Some idea of the fierceness of the fames may be gathered, however, when we state that Mr. Spathis's bar and Mr. Ipekian's cigarette stores opposite suffered. The frontage of the latter was almost totally destroyed by the heat acting on the woodwork and glass.
INSURANCE DETAILS. The following details as to the insurance will be of interest. The figures are only approximate :--
The total amount of the building insurance is £25,000
The stock of Messrs. Laurens & Co. was insured for about £20,000 and the stock of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi & Co. for about £10,000.
The following British insurance companies are affected :
Sun Insurance Office (Behrend) £ 3,500 Queen Fire Office (Barker)

The French companies are :L'Union (Sevastopoulo)

Mr. Constantine Meimarachi arrived from Cairo by this morning's first express to personally inspect the damage done.

div.head: PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: Large numbers of foreign pilgrims arrive at Suez daily en route to Mecoa. Owing to the cases of plague at Suez, they all have to be disinfected before embarking. The total number of Indian pilgrims who have arrived at Suez up to date is 240.

SAVOY SMALL DANCE. The small dance at the Savoy Hotel on Xmas eve was well attended, and the resta11rant was very full. Among the diners we noticed Hon. F. G. Morgan, with a party of 8, and Mrs. Webster, with another party of 8. Mr. Joseph Walton, M.P., was dining with Lord Edward Cecil and party. Mr. Peckham had a | party of 5, including Mr. and Mrs. ScottDalgleish. Dancing was kept up till midnight only, the next day being 'Xmas Day.
The restaurant was also full for supper, and we notice that these suppers are much in favor this year.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: KAFR AMAR COLLISION. A PASSENGER'S NARRATIVE.
div.p: Mr. D. K. Reid, of the firm of Reid and Barnard, writes to us on 'Xmas Day, from "between Assiout and Luxor," giving the following account of his experiences in the recent accident:

It has been my misfortune to have taken my part for a second time in an accident on the Egyptian State Railways. I was a passenger in the train which was thrown off the rails at Kafr Dawar three years ago, and I was again & passenger last night in the express "train de luxe" which was partially wrecked by a collision at Kafr Ammar. Our situation as passengers w precisely similar to that in which we found ourselves before, with the unfortunate difference that whereason that occasion weli had finished our dinner, we had on this occasion barely begun it, and the interruption was such as to preclude all possibility of continuing it.

Almost all the passengers, I think, were in the diping-car when the collision occurred. | ! Fortunately they were few in number and only filled one half of it, for, as you know, it is divided into two compartments. Had the other half, that nearest to the kitchen, contained passengers, the results would have been very 12 serious. As it was, of the three men who were at the moment either in this section of the car, or in the kitchen, one European waiter was badly cut and bruised; another was taken out with his leg broken and other injuries ;|I and the native cook was so badly crushed that he died & few hours later. The shock of the collision was severe. The dining-car was only separated from the engine and tender by at brake and luggage van. This was driven right into the dining car, annihilating the kitchen and two-thirds of one section; the wreckage which it carried with it stopping within a few feet of the door leading into the other part where the passengers were seated.

None of the carriages which made up the lo train left the line, and though the lights in the dining-car were extinguished by the lo shock, there was little confusion, and beyond | a few bruises no passenger received anyu injuries.

The position of the engines left no doubt as to how the accident occurred. They were locked together in close embrace as men who wrestle. For reasons no doubt good in them-li selves, the up train to Cairo was stationary | 1 at the Kafr Ammar platform on the down line. This appears to bave either provoked the ire or appealed to the sporting instinctst of the "train de luxe" mecanicien, who, disregarding all signals to the contrary, made for the stationary train at & pace which Ilt presume he considered necessary to effect its removal. The results, if not in precise la accordance with his expectations, were sufficiently important to warrant his detention.

Everything possible was done for the comfort and convenience of travellers by the officials of the aministration and the sleeping-car service; and a series of free meals was provided It between Minieh and Luxor as compensation for the loss of the restaurant car dinner. At the same time I should like to appeal to the railway It authorities to act with more despatoh after such regrettable incidents, in forwarding pas- sengers to their destinations. On this occasioni an engine was on the spot soon after the acci- t dent, and it would have been the matter of an If hour or two at most to have detached the lo uninjured carriages and sent them down to Ayat, where the 8 p.m. express from Cairo was r in waiting and together with the sleeping car could have been made up into one trainnecessarily with two engines--and sent on its

ay to Luxor. This was in fact the course adopted; unfortunately it was thought necessary to maintain the uninjured cars in situ until the arrival of railway officials from Cairo, with the result that & delay which should have been of two hours was prolonged into one of eight. I should not have called attention to this, had I not a vivid recollection of a similar delay which followed the Kafr Dawar accident, when within a few miles of Alexandria we were left for five hours, bereft of food and drink, to the tender mercies of the mosquitoes which infest that neighbourhood.

div.head: BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: It is stated that the third division of the Baltic Fleet is due to arrive at Port Said on or about the 31st inst.

div.head: CAIRO FETE COMMITTEE.
div.p: In our recent issues we have published some very interesting details on the subject of the Fête Comunittee for Cairo. The idea is a good one and we are glad to see that the scheme, which we have advocated for years past, has at last taken definite shape. With such names as those of Maitre Carton de Wiart, Major Kenney-Herbert, M. Cattaoui, the Hon. F. C. Morgan, Mr. Chas. Baebler, Nungovich Bey, Omar Bey Sultan, and Mr. Aspinali, we have no doubt that the efforts of the committee will meet with every success, provided that the public show some response in backing them up. The expenses will, of course, be considerable and we believe that it is estimated that over | £3,000 will have to be spent this season. The committee have decided to issue posters every month giving a list of the fêtes which are to take place, and handbills will also be distributed throughout the hotels and leading resorts. The committee will also institute various forms of amusement and entertainment for our visitors and we shall be glad to aid as much as lies in our power towards the successful attainment! of such a scheme. That something in this line can be done was evidenced by the great , success that attended the bataille de fleurs which was held in the grounds of the Ghezireh Casino last March by a small committee of local notabilities,

div.head: CHRISTMAS SERVICES.
div.p: ALL SAINTS CHURCH, CAIR The Christmas services at All Saints' durch were numerously attended. The Holy Communion was celebrated four times, at 6. a.m., 7.30 a.m., 8.30 a.m., and after morningervice. The number of communicants at the three celebrations was 254. The services wer conI ducted by the Very Rev. Dean Butcher, D. D., Rev Thompson Burns, M. A., and Rev. Douglas Thornton, M. A. The Dean to his text from Phil. 2.8 and pressed up his hearers the truth that as Christ to our nature upon Him so that He might experience the trials of humanity, so we should put our. selves in other people's places and try to understand them. He urged on all the Christ-I! mas duties of reconciliation and forgiveness of injuries.
The musical part of the service, directed by Mr. Peacock, was, as usual, admirable. The fine anthem, "In the beginning was the Word," by Allen, was given with precision and effect.
The solo, "Full of grace are thy lips," was | beautifully sung. The Te Deum s by

Berthold Tours, the Jubilate by Hay The service began with Hymn No. 61, "Christians Awake," and Hymn No. 60, "Hark the Herald Angels" (not according to the revised version of Hymns A. and M.) was sung wiile the offertory was being collected.
In the evening there was no sermon, but two carols, " 'Twas in Winter cold" and "Sleep! Holy Babe," were sung by the choir. The collections amounted to £42.14s. 0.
The decorators of the church relied for their effects on the graceful palms marking out the lines of architecture, and on a gorgeous | profusion of poinsettias in the chance

div.head: ST. ANDREW'S CHURCH, CAIRO. On Sunday lasť Christmas services were held in this church morning and evening, the officiating clergyman on both occasions being the Rev. A. C. W. Saunders, résident Scottish chaplain. Through the kindness of members of the congregation and others, the church was beautifully decorated for the occasion with evergreens and flowers. At the morning service there was a large congregation, who joined heartily in the singing, which included the well-known Christmas hymns "O come all ye 13 faithful" and "Hark the herald angels sing." Mr. Saunders took as his text Revelation 3,
div.p: 14, The Beginning of the creation of God." | There were, be said, two creations, the old and the new; and as the Pre-Incarnate think the Eternal Word was the beginning of the one, 80 was the lucernate Christ the beginning of the other. When man had fallen, it was God's purpose to restore the Divine Image in him and re-create him after a new pattern. This He did by infusing into him a new life from a new source. And the new source was the Incarnation of Jesus Christ. The work of the new creation began on the day when Son of God assumed our flesh. Christ took nature that He might transform it anew,that lle might enliven it with His perfect life, Hof an and Divine. Christmas was thus the fival of the beginning of God's new creatit. They celebrated this day the birthday of One who ushered in a new era in the biste sy of the Universe. They kept Christmas as a pemorial that God had stooped to be born fter the flesh in order that man might be bean anew of the Spirit.--A celebration of H y Communion followed, at which between and 40 received the Sacrament.
hroughene churches han Holyt

div.head: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH, RAMLEH.
div.p: The services throughout the day were well attended. At 11 a.m. the church was crowded to overflowing and additional chairs had to be li fetched. The early celebrations of the Holy Communion at 7.30 a.m. and 8.30 a.m. were taken by the Chaplain, Canon Ward. The other services were conducted by the Rev. R. F. Rynd, B.A., assistant chaplain. Thl offerings, for the day amounted to P.T. 99 and the communicants numbered 74.. Bath at the li morning and evening services & lection of carols was sung by the choir.

The church was very prettily decorated by the following ladies : Miss Alderson, Missi Atkin, Mrs. P. W. Carver, Miss Carver, Mias Charteris, Miss Harbord, Miss Hawkings, Miss Miles, Miss Moss, Miss Todd,, and Mrs. W. R. Williams. A plentiful supply of flowers and I plants was sent by Mrs. Allen, Miss Atkin, Mrs. Briscoe, Mrs. S. H. Carver, Mrs. P. W. Carver, Miss Charteris, Mrs. Dorling, Mrs. F. Haselden, Mrs. R. J. Moss, Mre Parkinson, Mrs. Ruffer, Judge Sandars, ang Mrs. G. A. Williams.

div.head: 'XMAS TREE AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Monday - The members pt the Cercle | International at Port Tewfik (Sc :) entertainTed about 300 children yesterday afternoon.

Dancing began at 3 p.m., and wys kept up to 5 o'clock, when refreshments were offered to the children. Shortly after they were taken to a beautifully decorated 'Xmas tree, illuminated with electric lights, in the large dancing-room of the club, and pretty presents were distributed to the children. The band played the whole time, which greatly contributed to the success of the entertainment.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMWAY COMPANY.—The well-known Belgian financier and the Chairman of the Board of the Cairo Tramway Company, M. Edouard Empain, is expected to arrive in Egypt from Europe this week. During his stay here, which will last about two months, he will confer with the Egyptian Government on a number of projects in connection with the development of the Cairo Tramway Company, Mr. Empain will stay at Shenkgard's Hotel, I where a large suite has been reserved for him,

div.p: The Queen's birthday was ofhcially celebrated here on the 1st inst. and lat midday salute of 21 guns was fired from shore in bonor of the occasion. Flags were flying over all the principal buildings, as well as on board H. M. 8. "Sealark" and S.G.S. Mukhbir.”.

The Beyram holidays commered on the 8th inst. In the morning, H. E. the Mudir of Suakin, Miralai Howard Bey, ld an official reception, which was attended by all the Army officers and Government officials, the notables, clergy, representaties of banks, shipping agents, and all the prin ipal European and native merchants. After the reception Howard Bey inspected the gard of honor furnished by the 3rd Battalion A. and three cheers were given by the troofor H.H. the Khedive. In the afternoon a lotball match took place outside the Suakin tes.

On the 9th and 10th athlete sports took place and proved to be very successful. The greasy pole event was the most amusing one, as about 100 natives tried bo walk on the pole to reach the log of mutton which was suspended at the end,' those that failed falling in the water. The members of the committee took their stand on the verandah of the new residence of Kaimakam Drury Bey, the controller ofSudan ports. The latter was unable to take an active shere in the organisation, owing to his being laid up wit his old complaint, rheumatic gout, whid he contracted whilst cutting the sudd on the Upper Nile. He, however, managed to tow the sports ensconced in an armchair his verandah. The men of H.M.S. "Sealarkould not take part in the sports as the ves put to sea on the 6th inst. for surveying wg k round Sheikh Barghout. She returned to Suakin on the (14th inst. | The Sudan Government Port Tug "Hawke" arrived here from Suez (where she had been in dry-dock) on the 10th inst. Mr. Lessone, lata chief storekeeper, Suakin-Atbara Railways, arrived by the "Hawke," having been in Europe on leave of absence for four months.

The Khedivial mail steamer "Rahmanieh" arrived here from Suez on the 12th inst. and the following 1st-class passengers landed here : El Bimbashi Spencer, Inspector, Suakin Mudi rieh; El Bimbashi Cox, cgnmanding half of the 3rd Battalion E. A., stat oned here ; Mr. Urquhart, engineer-contracto for the bridges of the Suakin-Atbara Railways accompanied by his principal engineers, Messrs. Mamprese and Felice, and a great number European and native workmen from Egypt. He brought also a large consignment of material and tools for making the bridges and about half a ton of dynamite to be used in the quarries. Mr. Urquhart is well-known in Egypt and the Sudan, as he has carried out several works in Khartoum for the Sudan Public Works Dept., and several works were execyted by him in connection with the Assouan Reservoir. Until the iron bridges are erected the Sudan Government Railways are making temporary wooden bridges under the supervision of Bimbashi Sowerby, R.E., Chief Engineet of Ways and Works, assisted by Mr. Bailly, head foreman of works, Suakin-Atbara Rai ays, who may probably have to go on the lis shortly to erect the temporary bridges now u fler construction.

div.head: SEAMEN'S HOME
div.p: The concert at the Seame's Home on the 23rd inst., of the benefit for the sailors in port, was one of the most enjoyable evening entertainments given there for some time. The ball was simply packed, and tho thanks of all present are due to the host and hostess, Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blomfi id, as also to the ladies and gentlemen who so sindly helped with the musical portion. A capit programme was provided, and the hearty applause and recalls testified to its appreciation by the audience. Mr. Hugh Blomfield opened with a couple of violin solos (a) Berceuse Blave (6) Perpetuo Mobile, rendered in quite & masterly manner. Miss Cohu then sang with much tasto "The sweetest girl in Dixie,” Mr. Nixon following with a capital rendering of "The Outpost's Vigil," and as an encore he gave "Will o' the Wisp." Some selections from the "Cingalee" were next given. The very pretty quartette, "Spite of all that Lovers 10," sung by Lady Blomfield, Miss MunGavin and Messrs. Nixon ar 1 Purvis, well deserved its encore, as also Mr. Byrne's Cingalee and Mr. Hugh Blomfield's clever impersonation of Chambuddy Ram in the comic songs That's all right" and "The Wonderful E lish Pot," which brought the first part of the entertainment to & close amidst peals of cughter.

Refreshments were passed round during the interval, and the second part of the concert commenced with a piano solo, a selection from "The Belle of New York," played by Miss Cohu in a spirited manner. The great feature of the evening's entertainment now followed, being selected parts of the comic opera "San Toy,” as played some months back at the Abbas Helmy Theatre; i.e., 1. "A posy from over the sea" (Poppy), 2. quartett and dance, "Pyn Ka Pong" (Poppy, Dudley, Drucker, and Li), 3. duet, "When we are wed,” (Poppy and Fo Hop), 4. duet and dane, "Samee Games," (Dudley and Li), 5. son and dance, "Pretty Little Chinee" (Dudleynd Li), 6. Song, "Me gettee out welly quick (Li). The following was the dramatis person : Poppy, Miss MunGavin ; Dudley, Mrs. Haylis; Lieut. Harvey Tucker and Fo Hop, Mr. Byrne ; Li, Mr. Hugh Blomfield. Each o these selections was encored and Poppy, Dalley, Lieut. Harvey Tucker, Fo Hop, and, last but not least Li, may congratulate themselves that they contributed in no small degree to the enjoyment of the evening. The piano accompani. ments were kindly undertaken by Lady Blomfield, Mrs. MunGavin, and Mrs. Baylis. The entertainment closed with "God Save the King," but prior to dispersing lusty cheers were given for Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield, and an extra one for those who saiated

div.head: THE NEW SUEZ CANAL PROJECT.
THE CONTENTIONS OF THE OTHER
SIDE
div.p: LONDON, Dec. 19th. It is an open secret that the Foreign Office is no more enamoured of the new Suez Canal project than it was of the proposal in 1883 ; and the promoters will, therefore, have a hard task set them to get their scheme sanctioned, if they ultimately decide to go forward with it.

The Suez Canal Company is not disposed to say anything with regard to the complaints which Sir Theodore Angier says are the cause of the scheme being revived. It is asserted, however, that the charges can be controverted if any real necessity for their disproval arises. Of the complaints the most specific is the alleged violation of an agreement concluded in London with M. de Lesseps in 1883, whereby it was arranged that the rates would be gradually reduced, and that no higher dividend than 25 per cent. would be paid until the rates went down to 5frs. a ton. Last year the dividend was 28 per cent., while the rates stood at 8f. 500.

It is pointed out, on the other hand, that this version does not accurately represent the terms of the agreement, which, it is said, took the form of an amicable arrangement and not of a contract, and was concluded on the understanding that if it were found to work unsatisfactorily it could be altered. In many respects, it is contended, concessions have been made in excess of the terms of the arrangement. With regard to the rates reductions have been made. At the date of the ägreement dues were at the rate of 10frs. & ton; at present they are 8f. 50c., with the prospect of a further reduction in 1906 of 50c. It is, of course, not disputed that a dividend of 26 per cent. was paid last year, but it is pointed out that only original shareholders benefit to that extent. The Suez Canal shares have been steadily rising in value for many years, and are at present quoted at 180, which means that to the majority of the shareholders they yield nothing like 26 per cent.
The opposition maintain their view, and intend to bring all the pressure to bear they possibly can in order to induce the Suez Canal directors to redress their grievances.

div.head: THE PRICE OF EGYPTIAN COTTON.
A SUGGESTION FROM FRANCE.
div.p: The following letter from a very large French spinner is sent us by a firm of cotton brokers at Liverpool to whom it has been addressed. Considering the developments since the date of the letter, the first words are rather prophetic :

"December 9, 1904. "My opinion is that Egyptian cotton is in the hands of speculators, and that, whatever happens, it cannot maintain its price. Now, the question is -- When will the decline come? In any case the spinner cannot go on paying present prices; it would mean laying in stocks at a great loss, because the use of Egyptian cotton yarn is going to be very much restricted. The interest for the spinner would therefore be to commence short time at once, and work only four days a week for two months. The mere announcement of such a decision would certainly have the effect of bringing down prices of Egyptian as compared with those of American. It is, in fact, only makers of sewing cotton who can pay high prices; manufacturers of cloth will not. As regards mercerised goods, they are quite out of fashion in America, and very likely the same thing will occur in England and on the Continent. And the demand for this article will fall off the more rapidly as the price of Egyptian cotton is so exorbitant. An understanding is therefore necessary between English and Continental spinners with a view to short time, and by this means prices will be brought down to a reasonable level. That is the only remedy for the speculative excesses.”

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui à midi et demi,
div.p: Au lieu d'une accentuation de la baisse, comme beaucoup le redoutaient, nous avons eu après Noël une bonne reprise sur la plupart des valeurs. Le repos de ces deux derniers jours aurait permis, parait-il, à la spéculation de se remettre de sa première panique et, de plus, les Banques se montreraient plus disposées à faire des avances que par le passé.
C'est donc en hausse que nous clôturons aujourd'hui. L'ouverture a été un peu indécise, mais sur les fort achats qui ont suivi les cours ont rapidement monté.

La Banque Nationale passe de 21 3/4 à 22 1/2, l'Agricole de 9 3/8 à 9 11/16, la Daïra de 21 1/16 à 21 1/4, la Crown Brewery de 214 à 224. la Salt and Soda de 35 à 37/9, la Banque d'Athènes de 113 à 117 1/2, la Nungovich de 9 à 9 1/16, l'Anglo-American Nile de 4 5/8 à 4 3/4, les Eaux du Caire de 990 à 1010, la Delta de 13 7/8 à 14 1/16, et la Ramleh Railway de 7 3/4 à 7 7/8.
Les Markets se maintiennent de 21/9 à 22 et la Delta Land de 31 à 3 15/16.
On ne s'attend pas, du moins pour le moment, à ce que la reprise s'accentue beaucoup, s'est déjà fort beau d'avoir obtenu les excellents résultats de ce matin,

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold purselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but wo wish, in spirit of fair play to all, to perthit - within portain nessAry limits-free discussiou.
THE PORT OF ALEXANDRIA.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTH.

Sir, -In your leading article on the 22nd inst. in reference to the above subject you did me the honour to refer to a short and somewhat meagre paper of mine, which you quoted from the Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce in Egypt. As the subject is now attracting a good deal of attention with reference to modern requirements, it may perhaps not be out of place to make a few retrospective remarks in connection with it. cr These are suggested to me by your observa- th tion that you fiud that maritime opinion of entirely differs from mine on some of the du suggestions I offer.

This sensible remark of yours seems to go to Y the root of the whole matter. I do not M pretend to be an authority on maritime på opinion, nor, to the best of my recullection, am I aware that any such authority has ever P been consulted with reference to the inner D harbour of Alexandria, or if he was, it is only too evident that his advice was never carried out. The barbour was design be ed by the late Sir Juhu Fowler, who was re then Eugineer-in-Chief to Ismail Pasha. i be Mr. Fuwler was an emineut engineer, at th the bead of his profession as a railway ca engineer, but no one in England ever considered him an authority ou port or harbour works.

Every one admits that the breakwater of at the outer harbour is a fine work, buth in its na conception and execution ; the inner harbour G has well-built quays which reflect much credit buth on the resident engineer and contractors, but it only requires little more than a super-R ficial kuowledge of such matters to recognisem that it was uot desigued by the hand of a b master. I do not hesitate to say that had this been done by either of the four or five engineers B who were at that time the recognised leaders in this branch of their profession, the result would have been very different.

I was for a short time an assistant engineer on the staff of one of these gentlemen, the late Sir Juhu Coode, then Engineer-in-Chief for the Portland breakwater, one of the finest works of the kind eyer carried out, and se & veral other harbours, both on the English coast and abroad. For several years after I 4 lett his service, I watched his work with a interest, and I feel sure that if the Egyptian Government had then consulted him and carried out his advice, the inner harbour would have been much more useful than it now is.

When one reflects on the way in which worki was done iu Ismail Pasha's time, it is wonderful that the harbour should be so good as it is. I will give an instance which came under my personal obseryation in 1872.

Previous to 1869, Ismail Pasha had three sugar factories which brought him in a considerable revenue. With more haste than discretion, he ordered, at the same time, ten more factories larger than the other ; ho paid liberally for them, but gave their makers 80 litale time to complete them under heavy penalay, that they had hardly any opportunity of studying their details to the best advantage.

The foundations and buildings were begun in such a hurry, under the Khedive's personal directions, that little regard was paid to future requirements, and it was not astonishing that the result was unsatisfactory. Ismail Pasha had in his service engineers who gave him good advice as to requisite improvements, but he thought he would go one better, and brought out from England, at great expense, a Commission consisting of three members, each of whom was eminent in his particular sphere ; they knew a great deal about many things, but unfortunately nothing about sugar factories.

No doubt many circumstances contributed *to the ill-success of the scheme, but I believe that the above incident marked the parting of the ways between success and failure, of what might otherwise have been a prosperous undertaking. But misfortune followed it still further. It was decided to sell several of the factories, but only one of them was sold at à fairly good price, and the Egyptian Government rather uufortunately undertook to deliver it at Mauritius. They wanted to do it as cheaply as possible, and sent the principal parts in one of their own ships, an old one, not I believe very seaworthy; at all events she sunk in the Red Sea, and it was only after the cargo was entirely lost they found out that someone had forgotten to insure it!
This digression is only intended to remind your readers, that money was not always well spent in Egypt in those days.

If I have ventured to make some slight criticisms on the design of some parts of the harvour of Alexandria, I hasten to say how vas' an improvement it was on anything which existed here before, and it is undoubtedly one of the finest relics of an extravagant age.
I am, etc.,
ANGLO-AMERICAN HOSPITAL.
To The EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,--As an old resident I consider your strictures on the Anglo-American community as regards their financial support of the above institution as uncalled-for as was the institution itself. It was not wanted and, as has been proved, was not required. There were other hospitals already in existence on which the money collected would have been far better spent. Why in the name of heaven should you "rattle" the dual community for not supporting a scheme which was toisted on it stillborn. Those who remember how the idea of the hospital originated will appreciate the last remark.
I am, etc.,

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: The Admiralty has placed the armoured cruiser "Essex" (Captain R. B. Farquhar) at the disposal of Field-Marshal H.R.H. the Duke of Connaught, K. G., who, in discharge of his duties as luspector-General of His Majesty's Army, will leave England early in the New Year to inspect the garrisons of Gibraltar, Malta, and Egypt. The Duke will be accompanied by the Duchess and his staff. Next month the "Essex" will be taken in hand at Portsmouth for the reception of the Duke and Duchess and their respective suites.

It seems that the Army Council has thought better of it, and the 56th Battery R. F. A. with remain for the present at Cairo. Amongst the best kuown military experts the reduction of the army of occupation-particularly the cavalry arm--in Egypt is greatly deprecated.

Breve: Lieutenant-Colonel J. Fergusson, D.S.O., Grenadier Guards, late Adjutant General at Cairo, has been formally promoted lieutenant-colonel commanding the 3rd Battalion Grenadier Guards ut Aluershot.

The order for Captain E. H. Llewellyn, Ruya. Inuiskilliug Fusiliers, to revert to reximental duty with the 1st Battalion at Derry, has been caucelled, and he will be employed for another term of service with the King's African Ritles. He was lately adjutaut and quartermaster of the disbanded 2ud (Central Africa) Battaliou.

It is understood that the sum of £2,500,000 is to be spent ius re-arıing our horse and field batteries with the new guus at home and abroad. The manufacture of the 12) and 185 pounders will be divided between the Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, Sir William Armstrong and Co., and Messrs. Vickers, Sons, anu | Maxim.

div.head: WHY KIDNEY DISEASE IS SO SERIOUS.
div.p: Kidney disease is serious, because it comes on so quietly. It has many symptoms, bu often they are mistaken for other diseases. Headaches, rheamatism, a nervous, irritable condition, weak heart, dropsy, sleeplessness," an always tired feeling, yellow complexion, unnatural urine, too much or too little urinethese are just as much symptoms of kidney disease as backaches, gravel, bladder troubles,
etc.
1 Kidney disease may have been working in the system for years before the patient suspected the cause of his trouble. That's the danger

Treat the kidneys at the first sign of any ailment. That is the only safe way. Keep them well, and they will keep you well. Doan's backache kidney pills help the kidney to filter the blood, and remove from it all disease breeding impurities. That explains their success.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: * RACING
PE 2
HELOUAN FIRST WINTER MEETING.
The following is the programme of, and the entries for the races to be held at Helouan on Saturday, 31st inst., at 2 p.m., under the rules and co-operation of the Khedivial Sporting Club :

FIRST RACE, 2 p.m. CRITERION STAKES : of P.T. 2,500, 1st horse to receive P.T. 2,000, 2nd P.T. 300 and 3rd P.T. 200. For maiden Arab ponies that have never won a race of any description or value. Weight for age and inches. Distance 5 furlongs. Entrance P.T. 200.
Entries :-Sihame, Miasser, Fahr, Soldat, Mamdook, Inspector.

SECOND RACE, 2.30 P.M. MAIDEN GALLOWAY: of P.T. 2,500. 1st horse to receive P.T. 2,000, 2nd P.T. 300 and 3rd P.T. 200. For maiden Arab galloways. Weight for age and inches ; winners of a race of any description of the advertised value of P.T. 2,000, 7 lbs. extra. Distance 3/4 mile. Entrance P.T. 200.
Entries :- Rainbow, Macdonald, Seyad II.,
Toga

THIRD RACE, 3 p.m. SAHARA STAKES: of P.T. 13,000, 2nd horse to receive P.T. 2,000 and 3rd horse P.T. 1,000 out of the stakes. For maiden (at nomination) Arab ponies. Weight for age and inches with penalties, reduced 7lbs. Distance 7 furlongs.

Entry by subscription and nomination as follows :- Subscription on 1st June, 1904, P.T. 200, with P.T, 200 on nomination on 1st October, 1904, and with a further charge or P.T. 200 if left in after the 1st of December 1904. Unless 20 subscriptions are received the race will not be considered to have filled.
N.B. This race, having been published before the revision of the Khedivial Sporting Club Rules, will be run under the old scale of weights.
Entries :-Sakaf, Kohelan Tair, Munir, Abou Arkoub, Ribico, Aeolus, Gossa, Selim, Nimrod, Game Chicken, Firefly, Roland, Peacock, Jean, Sattam, Fantasia.

FOURTH RACE, 3.30 p.m. DESERT HANDICAP : of P.T. 8,000, 2nd horse to receive P.T. 1,000 and 3rd horse P.T. 500 ont of the stakes. For Arab horses. Top-weight not to exceed 11st Distance 1! miles. Entrance on 1st October, 1904, P.T. 400, on 1st December, 1904, when the race closes, P.T. 600. Unless 10 entries are received the race will not be considered to have filled.
Entries:-Royalist, Suuvi, Sabian, Shewiman, Mizzaud.

FIFTH RACE, 4 p.m. TRIAL PLATE: of P.T. 2,500, 1st horse to receive P.T. 2,000, 2nd P.T. 300 and 3rd P.T. 200, For maiden Arab horses that have never won a race of the advertised value of. P.T. 1,000 or more. Weight for age. Galloways allowed 4lbs. Distance mile. Entrance P.T. 200.
Entries:-Sihame, Miasser, Macdonald, Fahr, Napa, Soldat, Aeolus, Gordius, Magnoon, Don Quichotte, Fil-de-Fer (late Husko).
SIXTH RACE, 4.30 p.m. CONSOLATION STAKES : of P.T. 1.300. First 3 horse to receive P.T. 1,000, second P.T. 200

and third P.T. 100. For all beaten horses. Catch weights ; over 11st. for horses, 10st. (lbs. for galloways, 10st. for ponies. Distance bout 1 mile. Entrance P.T. 100. Entries close 5 minutes after the 5th race.

Makers of high class steam engines and boilers for British, Colonial, and Foreign Governments. Celebrated for ECONOMY and DURABILITY.
Philadelphia Sweden Denmark Germany etc., etc.
Awarded only Gold Medal, ever given by the Royal So. of Arts and Gold Medals at the following Exhibitions:- London; Vienna 1873; Paris
Compound Portable Engines. Horizontal Engines, Vertical Engines Quick Speed Engines Engines for Electric Light
Paxman Flue & Tube Dry Back Boilers
Verticals, Langasrite & Compound Steam Engines.

Davey Paxman & Co.'s Trip Geared Engine gives off a full horse power for one hour at 1 1/4 lbs. of fuel. At the great trial of Com- pound, Portable and Single Cylinder Steam Engines by the Royal Agricultural Society at Newcastle open to the whole world, Davey Paxman & Co. took the only prizes offered, establishing a record which has not yet been equalled.
